THE TRACTATE
Masseketh Sefer Torah, 'the Tractate on the Torah Scroll', deals with the preparation, correct writing and proper handling of sacred scrolls, particularly the Pentateuch which is used for the reading of the lections in the statutory religious services in the Synagogue.

Forming part of the collection known as Massektoth Ḳeṭannoth, it belongs also to the smaller collection, Sheba' Massektoth Ḳeṭannoth, 'The Seven Minor Tractates', which is the earliest collection of its kind in the Talmudic literature. All the seven are of great antiquity in their main contents and have their origin in the early period of oral traditions, when the writing down of such traditions was generally forbidden. Their author was a Palestinian who lived before the redaction of the Mishnah (beginning of the third century C.E.).

In the history of Rabbinic literature these tractates are of considerable importance because they represent the earliest digests dealing with a particular subject in a compact, comprehensive and detailed set of rules. Such regulations are scattered throughout the numerous pages of the Talmud, embedded in long and intricate discussions, together with material which has no direct bearing on the subject under treatment.

Although most of the rules in this tractate are to be found in the Tannaitic teaching in the Talmudic literature—Mishnah, Baraitha, and the Palestinian and Babylonian Gemara—twelve rules occur in it which cannot be traced in those sources. These are contained in II, 9f., III, 5-9, and V, 1-3, 6, 8.

There is a very close relationship between Masseketh Sefer Torah and the first five chapters of Soferim, the tractate on 'Scribes', and both probably assumed their present form in the Geonic period. It is also clear that the compiler of Soferim was acquainted with this tractate and drew largely upon it,★★ [I. H. Weiss, Dor (1904), II, pp. 224f., maintains that Sefer Torah is an abstract from Soferim.] but whereas Sefer Torah is characterized by a simple and direct style and a clear cut system of rules, Soferim has numerous interpolations, amplifications and much irrelevant matter. The numbering of the chapters corresponds in the two tractates so far as they overlap, but there is a difference in the length of the respective chapters, their contents, and the numeration and extent of the rules.
<small>ANALYSIS</small>

Chap. I prescribes the writing materials that must alone be used for sacred scrolls; the languages permitted in the originals and translations; indicates some deviations in the Septuagint from the Masoretic text; and deals also with the rules concerning the sheets, columns, and open and closed sections in the sacred scrolls.

Chap. II indicates the spaces that must be left between letters, words, columns and books in a scroll; the number of columns in a sheet; the width and length of columns and scrolls; the size of the upper and lower margins; blank spaces at the beginnings and ends of scrolls; special arrangement of lines in certain sections; the rollers, sewing and mending; and the disposal of outworn sheets.

Chap. III deals with the kind of books that may be written on one scroll; the extent of the spaces that must separate books of the Pentateuch and books of the Prophets respectively; which scrolls may be separated into smaller books; degrees of sanctity in the various sacred writings; palimpsests; procedure in case of scribal errors; manner of rolling and unrolling scrolls, and how many columns at a time are to be unrolled during the Scriptural reading; their reverential handling; and the respectful use of foodstuffs.

Chap. IV lists the divine names that may not be erased, the names that are always sacred and the words with the same spelling which are secular; and prohibits the profane use of any of the sacred names.

Chap. V discusses cases of error in the writing of divine names, concentration of thought and reverence when divine names are written; procedure when such names are written on a person's body, on an article of furniture, the horn of an animal or any other object; the writing of small scrolls for children's instruction; and the storage of disused sacred writings.
I. W. SLOTKI.

RULE 1. It is not permitted to write a scroll of the Torah1(1) The scroll of the Pentateuch used for the lections in public worship. on skins of ritually unclean cattle or on skins of ritually unclean wild animals, nor may they2(2) The parchment sheets of which the scroll is made up. be sewn with [their] sinews or [the parchment rolls of tefillin] be wound with their hair. It is an oral prescription delivered to Moses at Sinai that [these] shall be written on the skins of ritually clean cattle, or on skins of ritually clean wild animals, that they shall be sewn together with ritually clean sinews, [that the tefillin rolls] shall be wound with ritually clean hair, and that the writing be done with ink, because [this latter requirement] has support in Scripture, And I wrote them with ink in the book.3(3) Jer. XXXVI, 18.

RULE 2. It is permitted to write [sacred scrolls] on skins of nebeloth and on skins of ṭerefoth and there is no need to consider the possibility of their having been pierced at the animal's heart.4(4) It was a heathen practice to remove the heart from a live animal to offer it as a sacrifice, and this, in Rabbinic law (Mishnah 'A.Z. 29b, Sonc. ed., p. 145) rendered the entire animal, including its skin, forbidden as an idolatrous offering.

RULE 3. Skins5(5) Before they were dressed; but dressed skins may be bought only from trustworthy persons who can testify that the dressing had been done in accordance with the law. for the [sacred] books, tefillin and mezuzoth may be bought anywhere, and one need not consider the possibility that they might be skins that were pierced at the animal's heart.

RULE 4. The writing on ḳelaf must be on the side of the flesh, and on gewil it must be on the side of the hair; and if one changed the one for the other [the scroll] may not be used for the lection [in the statutory services].

RULE 5. [Sacred texts]6(6) Mentioned in Rule 1. may not be written on difthera, a tablet or erased paper;7(7) Others 'palimpsest'. GRA in Sof. I, 5 omits 'erased'. nor with coal,8(8) Or, 'black pigment'. shoe-black, or ink containing gum or vitriol. Vitriol may not be added to the ink.

RULE 6. R. Jacob said in the name of R. Meir: Vitriol may be added to the ink. R. Judah said: R. Meir's statement about [writing with ink containing] vitriol applies to [the whole] Torah9(9) Cf. 'Erub. 13a [Sonc. ed., p. 82). except the section dealing with a suspected wife.10(10) Num. V, 11ff. R. Jacob retorted: [R. Meir] said, 'Except the section dealing with a suspected wife', [by which he meant that] only in the special scroll11(11) A small scroll on which were written the curses that would befall an unfaithful wife. which [was used] in the Temple [must the ink contain no vitriol] because [the writing] had to be blotted out.12(12) Cf. Num. ibid. 23f.
<small>RULE 7</small>. R. Simeon b. Laḳish said in the name of R. Meir, who had it from R. Ishmael, that vitriol may be added to the ink.

RULE 8. [Sacred texts]13(13) Mentioned in Rule 1. may not be written in [obsolete] Hebrew characters or in the Median, Elamitic or Greek languages.14(14) According to Meg. 9a (Sonc. ed., p. 48) it is permitted to write the Torah in Greek, though this is not allowed in the case of tefillin and mezuzoth. Seventy Elders wrote the Torah for king Ptolemy15(15) Assumed to be Ptolemy Philadelphus who reigned in Egypt, 285-247 B.C.E., and who arranged for the Greek Version, the Septuagint, to be made, as narrated in Sof. I, 8 (cf. the notes ad loc.). in Greek, and that day was as ominous for Israel as the day on which the Golden Calf was made, since the Torah could not be adequately translated.

RULE 9. They [all] introduced [the same] thirteen alterations:16(16) For a comparison of these variants with the Heb. text, cf. on Sof. I, 8. 'God created in the beginning'; 'I shall make a man in image and likeness'; 'And He finished on the sixth [day] and rested on the seventh [day]'; 'Male and female He created him'; 'Come let Me go down'; 'And Sarah laughed among her relatives, saying'; 'For in their anger they slew oxen and in their self-will they digged up a stall'; 'And Moses took his wife and his children and set them upon a carrier of men'; 'Now the time that the children of Israel dwelt in the land of Canaan and in the land of Egypt was four hundred and thirty years'; 'I have not taken one desirable thing from them'; 'And the [beast] with small legs'; 'Which the Lord thy God hath allotted unto all the peoples to give light under the whole heaven'; 'And they offer sacrifices to the sun or the moon or any of the host of heaven which I commanded should not be served'.

RULE 10. [Sacred scrolls] must not be written in gold. It is related that, in an Alexandrian scroll17(17) Cf. note to Sof. I, 9. of the Torah, the divine names were written in gold, and when the matter came before the Sages they decided that it should be stored away.18(18) lit. 'it shall be hidden', i.e. not used for the lections.

RULE 11. If Hebrew words were written in Aramaic or Aramaic words in Hebrew, if Ha'azinu was written in continuous lines,19(19) Cf. Sof. I, 10, n. 44, for the correct arrangement. or if the breaking up [of the lines] was not done according to the rule, the scroll may not be used for the lections.

RULE 12. If one finished [writing nearly] all the scroll [of the Torah] and less than a column of text remained, one need not hesitate to extend the writing so as to make of this a small column on its own.20(20) The extension of a short passage over a full column is done either by enlarging the characters or, according to others, by making each successive line shorter than the one preceding it.

RULE 13. If an open section was written as a closed one or vice versa, the scroll must be stored away. What is an open section? One which commences at the beginning of a line. How much space must there be at the end of a line so that the section beginning at the next line may be called an open one? A space on which may be written a name of three letters.21(21) The opinion of Maimonides, which has been adopted, is that space must be left for three words, each of three letters (cf. Y.D. CCLXXV, §2).

RULE 14. Should an entire section be finished at the end of a column, if one [blank] line remained and [the next] section is a closed one, [the scribe] begins it in the middle of the line; but if it is an open section, he begins at the top [of the next column] and leaves that line [blank].22(22) Cf. Sof. I, 14.

RULE 1. Sufficient space must be left between words1(1) lit. 'between name and name'. so that they may be distinguished, and between letters so that they be not mixed. If the letters were mixed up or a break made in the middle of a word, the scroll must not be used for the lection in the statutory services.

RULE 2. [It is permitted] to insert between columns two letters from a long word, but not from a short one. If, however, [the part of a longer word forms] a short word on its own,2(2) e.g. in a word like yimlok (he will reign) the last two letters can form an independent short word lak (to thee). it is forbidden [to insert it between the columns].

RULE 3. In a Torah scroll the space of two finger-breadths must be left [between columns], but in scrolls of the Prophets and in those of Pentateuchs3(3) Intended for ordinary reading or study, and not for the public lections. a space of one thumb-breadth [only].

RULE 4. In the lower margin of a Torah scroll the space of a handbreadth is left, and in the upper margin two-thirds of a handbreadth;4(4) lit. 'two parts of a handbreadth'. This is also the reading of V and M in Sof. II, 4. According to Men. 30a (Sonc. ed., p. 195) and H in Sof. loc. cit. the upper margin must be three finger-breadths wide. but in scrolls of the Prophets and Pentateuchs three finger-breadths in the lower margin and two finger-breadths in the upper. In all these cases5(5) lit. 'here and there'. if it is desired to extend [the margins] this may be done, provided they do not exceed [the space of] the written matter.
<small>RULE 5</small>. Between the books in a Torah scroll a vacant space of four lines must be left, and in a scroll containing the Twelve Prophets three lines.

At the end of a scroll and at its beginning sufficient [parchment] must be left to wind6(6) Reading with many authorities lehaḳḳif. V reads lehaḳim 'to raise up'. [it round the scroll]. In a Torah scroll no limit has been prescribed, but a roller should be attached at the end of the scroll and there is no need to do this at its beginning.7(7) This regulation does not agree with Sof. II, 5.

RULE 6. A sheet of a Torah scroll must contain not less than three columns and not more than eight. In the case of ḳelaf parchments no limit was prescribed, [62b] and one may add [as many columns] as desired provided only there are not less than three columns [to the sheet].

RULE 7. If one finished [writing nearly] all the book8(8) This refers either to one book of the Prophets or to several of them written in one scroll. and one column of text remained, one need not hesitate to make of it a separate small sheet.

<small>RULE 8</small>. If a sheet [of a Torah scroll] is worn out, one may not remove two [columns only] and replace them by two new columns; but three columns should be removed and replaced by three new ones, and the new columns must be written in the same size as the original script.

RULE 9. The width of a column [in a Torah scroll] must be such as to be recognizable at one glance,9(9) Accordingly, not more than three Hebrew words, each of ten letters, may be written in a line. If the column is wider, the reader experiences difficulty in passing from line to line. and in a small scroll not less than a handbreadth. R. Jose b. Judah says: It must not be less than the width of three fingers.

RULE 10. The height10(10) lit. 'length'. of [a scroll] must not be greater than its circumference,11(11) When rolled up, so according to B.B. 14a (Sonc. ed., p. 67); lit. 'its width'. nor its circumference greater than its height, but they must be exactly alike,12(12) lit. 'takes the middle course'. and this is the most correct procedure.

RULE 11. A Torah scroll may not consist half of gewil [and half of ḳelaf, but it may consist half of gewil]13(13) The words of this Rule enclosed within square brackets are added from Sof. II, 10, q.v. If 'although' is altered to 'because', the text will make sense but will be contrary to the Rule in Sof. loc. cit. and half [of the ḳelaf] of deers, although this is not the best procedure.

RULE 12. [A tear in a Torah parchment sheet] may not be joined with glue, nor is it permitted to write on a patch, nor may [the sheets] be sewn together on the written side. R. Simeon b. Eleazar said in the name of R. Meir: [A torn sheet] may be joined with glue and it is permitted to write on a patch, but it is forbidden to do the sewing14(14) So according to GRA, H and M in Sof. II, 11. V reads here as in Sof. 'the writing'. on the written side. If a scroll15(15) Other than a Torah scroll. is torn, a patch may be placed on the outside.

RULE 1. It is permissible to join the Torah and the Prophets in one scroll, according to R. Judah; but the Sages say: The Torah and the Prophets must be written in separate scrolls.1(1) According to GRA (in Sof. III, 1) who adopted the reading of B.B. 13b (Sonc. ed., p. 66): 'it is permissible to fasten the Torah, the Prophets and the Hagiographa together (in one scroll)'.

RULE 2. Between a book of the Prophets and another one should not leave the same [empty space] as between two books of the Torah; but in each case the space must be that which has been prescribed for it.2(2) i.e. four lines between books of the Torah and three between the books of the Prophets. Furthermore [a book of the Prophets]3(3) If the preceding book ended at the foot of a column. must begin at the top.4(4) Of the next column, the reason being that, if the books of the Prophets were separated one from the other, the beginning of each book would commence at the top of a column. This does not apply to Torah scrolls, which may never be cut up into separate books.

RULE 3. A Torah scroll5(5) Which contains all the five books of Moses. may not be made into [separate] books of the Pentateuch, because it is forbidden to reduce a major sanctity6(6) The Torah scroll in its entirety. to a minor sanctity.7(7) A section of the Pentateuch. From scrolls containing sections of the Pentateuch, however, it is permitted to make up a Torah scroll. When may this be done? When the measurements8(8) Of all the scrolls that are to be joined together. and the number of the lines9(9) In each column. are alike.

It is not permissible to join together two sections of the Pentateuch or one and a half of them to form a single scroll.10(10) Since it might be mistaken for a proper Torah scroll. But if it was intended11(11) When these were written. that additional scrolls be attached to them,12(12) To complete a full Torah scroll. it is permissible.

RULE 4. If a Torah scroll has spaces or stops [to mark] the beginning of verses, it may not be used for the lections.13(13) Because all proper Torah scrolls must conform to the original without any deviations. [Similarly] if a letter has been engraved or joined to another, the scroll may not be used for the lections.

RULE 5. A scroll [some of whose letters] are faded may not be used for the public lections.14(14) So H and GRA in Sof. III, 8. V reads 'one shall not rewrite [the letters] in it'. R. Simeon b. Eleazar says: If the outline [of the effaced letters] is distinguishable, it is permitted [to rewrite them].

RULE 6. A scroll of the Torah in which a whole line15(15) This is the reading in Sof. III, 9. V reads here 'one letter'. is faded may not be used. If the greater part of a line is faded and the smaller part intact, the use of the scroll is permitted.

RULE 7. Not more than four16(16) And not less than three (cf. Sof. III, 10). columns of the Torah scroll may be unrolled [at one time during the reading of the lection] but there is no objection to the reading of ten [columns] in one [lection].

RULE 8. A scribe may not put upon the written part [of a Torah scroll] a reed-pen with ink on it;17(17) So according to Sof. III, 11. The text in V is meaningless. nor may he take hold of the sheets of parchment and thereby unroll [the scroll]; nor may he18(18) This is the reading in Sof. III, 11. V reads 'but he should'. grasp the parchments to extract the written sheets;19(19) Which are rolled up; lit. 'and bring forth the writing without'. nor may he remove a scroll from its [case] by shaking it out. All these [restrictions], however, are relaxed in the case of official revisers of Scriptural scrolls.

<small>RULE 9</small>. It is not permissible to place a Torah scroll on a chair and to lean on it with one's elbows while reading; so according to R. Nehemiah. It is not permissible to place it over a chair [with its sheets] hanging down while it is read in the manner of ordinary documents, because [sacred] books must not be treated with disrespect.

RULE 10. A Torah scroll may not be placed on a bed and [certainly]20(20) Cf. N.Y. on Sof. III, 13. The insertion of 'certainly' avoids an anticlimax. not at its foot or under it; nor may one sit21(21) lit. 'that one may sit'. on a bed while a [Torah] scroll rests on it. It is related that R. Eliezer22(22) In Sof. III, 13, 'R. Eleazar'. once sat [unknowingly] on a bed on which a [Torah] scroll lay, and [when he realized it] he jumped up as if a snake had bitten him. [Such respect is shown for the Torah] because Scripture declares, Ye shall eep My sabbaths, and reverence My sanctuary23(23) Lev. XIX, 30.—it is not the Sabbaths that one reverences but Him Who commanded [to observe them], for Scripture declares, This is my God, and I will glorify Him24(24) Ex. XV, 2. [which means,]25(25) Connecting we'anwehu (I will glorify Him) homiletically with na'eh (beautiful) and understanding it as 'I will serve Him in a beautiful manner'. I will perform the commandment in a beautiful way to His glory.26(26) lit. 'before Him'. Such is the interpretation of R. Ishmael. R. 'Aḳiba expounds it: I will expatiate on His excellencies.27(27) Heb. na'oth, lit. 'beauties', excellent attributes. Abba Saul explains it: I will be like Him,28(28) He explains we'anwehu as the equivalent of 'ani wahu (I and He). i.e. as He is gracious and merciful so be thou gracious and merciful.

RULE 11. Foodstuffs may not be treated with disrespect. One may not sit on a basket containing dates or dried figs;29(29) Because they might be crushed and spoilt. but he may sit on a basket that contains pulse and also on a cake of pressed figs, because it is customary to do so in such cases.30(30) Pulse and dried figs are not spoilt by sitting on them.

RULE 12. Foodstuffs may not be used as a covering. R. Meir says: Any fruit which has a husk may be [used as a covering]. R. Judah says: Any fruit which has a stem or a stalk31(31) Whereby it can be lifted if it should happen to fall into the contents of the vessel it covered. may be [used as a covering].32(32) Since it would not be necessary to throw it away after use. Foodstuffs may not be eaten with the aid of foodstuffs33(33) Using them, e.g., in place of a spoon. unless they are consumed simultaneously.34(34) And would not be thrown away.

RULE 1. The following divine names may not be erased, viz.1(1) lit. 'he who writes'. Alef-lamed-he-yod-mem,2(2) Meaning 'God'. Alef-daleth-nun-yod,3(3) Translated 'Lord'. Yod-he-waw-he,4(4) Composing the Tetragrammaton. Shaddai,5(5) i.e. 'Almighty'. Ẓeba'oth,6(6) Meaning '[Lord of] hosts'. 'Eheyeh-'asher-'eheyeh.7(7) I am that I am (Ex. III, 14). R. Jose says: Ẓeba'oth is generally treated as a secular noun.8(8) Which may therefore be erased.

RULE 2. If one writes 'El9(9) It can mean 'to' or 'God' so far as the consonants are concerned. it may be erased;10(10) It is presumed to be the preposition 'to'. This Rule is omitted in Sof. IV, 2. if 'El of Alef-lamed-he-yod-mem or Yod-he of the four letters [of the Tetragrammaton],11(11) Which are Yod-he-waw-he. they may not be erased, because there are divine names corresponding to them.
<small>RULE 3</small>. All prefixes or suffixes connected with a divine name may be erased.
RULE 4. All ordinary words the letters of which are the same as those of a divine name may be erased.12(12) Because they possess no sanctity.

RULE 5. In For the Lord your God, He is God of gods,13(13) Deut. X, 17. the first [two]14(14) i.e. your God He is God. are sacred and the last15(15) Of gods, signifying 'judges' or 'princes'. is secular. In Lord of lords,16(16) ibid. the first is sacred and the second secular. In the God of Abraham17(17) Gen. XXXI, 53. it is sacred; in the god of Nahor18(18) ibid. Nahor did not worship the true God. it is secular, and in the god of their father19(19) ibid. Terah (their father) was an idolater. it is secular. In Thou shalt not revile God,20(20) Ex. XXII, 27. [the noun may bear] a sacred or a secular meaning.21(21) It may refer to God or judges. R. Ishmael22(22) In Sof. IV, 5, 'R. Simeon'. maintains that the noun is sacred.

RULE 6. All nouns in the Torah [signifying God] that are mentioned in connection with Abraham are sacred except the first.23(23) The verse, And he said: My lord, if now I have found favour in thy sight (Gen. XVIII, 3), because my lord was addressed to the leader of the three angels R. Hanina the son of R. Joshua's brother holds that it is sacred.24(24) In his opinion my Lord was addressed to God.

RULE 7. All names in the Torah mentioned in connection with Lot are secular25(25) There is only one secular name in the Lot passages, and the Tetragrammaton occurs twice. The word 'all' is not intended to be taken literally (cf. N.Y. on Sof. IV, 7). except the last.26(26) Viz. And Lot said unto them: 'Oh, not so my Lord' (Gen. XIX, 18). Lot's address to the angels is understood as ending at not so, and his petition to God then begins, My Lord, behold, etc. [So the Targum and Shebu. 35b, Sonc. ed., pp. 205f.] [All names] in the story of Micah27(27) Judg. XVIIf. are secular, even [when they begin with] Yod-he.28(28) The Tetragrammaton. In [the account of] Naboth29(29) 1 Kings XXI. they are sacred even [when they begin with] Alef-lamed.30(30) Meaning elsewhere 'God'.

RULE 8. In God standeth in the congregation of God, in the midst of the judges31(31) The Heb. has the consonants of the divine name. He judges,32(32) Ps. LXXXII, 1. [the divine name] is used as sacred33(33) In God standeth. and as secular.34(34) The name bearing the meaning of judges. In God delivereth me to35(35) Heb. 'el (to) which is the same consonants as the word for 'God'. the ungodly,36(36) Job XVI, 11. the first is sacred and the second37(37) 'el in the sense of 'to'. secular. In For hath any said unto God,38(38) ibid. XXXIV, 31. the first ['el] is secular and the second sacred. [In the verse] And let my cry have no39(39) Heb. על, the same consonants as those of the name of God. resting-place,40(40) ibid. XVI, 18. In Sof. IV, 9 the analysis is extended to the continuation of the verse. etc., [the words whose consonants are the same as those of a divine name] are secular. In God hath given command to speed me41(41) 2 Chron. XXXV, 21. [the name] is sacred. In Forbear thee from meddling with God, Who is with me,42(42) ibid. the name is sacred, according to the view of R. Jose b. Judah. In O God, the proud are risen up against me,43(43) Ps. LXXXVI, 14. the name is sacred but the reader must pause in his reading [after God].44(44) In the absence of the pause, the adjective proud might erroneously be taken as qualifying God.

RULE 1. If [a scribe] wrote a sacred name twice,1(1) lit. 'he who writes two sacred names'. he retains the first and erases the latter.2(2) The first is retained because it was properly written; the second is erased because it was written in error. R. Judah says: If the latter occurred at the end of a column, he erases the first and retains the latter.3(3) [In Sof. V, 1, the reading is: 'R. Judah says: If the first occurs at the end of a column'. Here H reads: 'If the latter occurs at the beginning of a column'. Either of these must be substituted for V because the idea is that] it spoils the appearance to leave a blank space at the beginning of the top line of a column.

RULE 2. If [the scribe wrote] a secular noun twice,4(4) lit. 'two secular names'. he retains the first and wipes away the latter.5(5) While the ink is still wet. R. Judah says: If the latter was at the top of a column,6(6) [Cf. Sof. V, 2, n. 6.] he wipes away the first and retains the latter.

RULE 3. If a scribe writes Yehudah and omits the daleth he inserts it above the line. If he intended to write the Tetragrammaton7(7) The four-lettered name Yod-he-waw-he. Lit. 'the name, he wrote the name', apparently a misprint. and wrote Yehudah8(8) Yod-he-waw-daleth-he. instead, he alters the daleth to he9(9) This is done by adding a short vertical line to the daleth. and wipes away the final letter he.

RULE 4. If it was required to write Yehudah but [the scribe] intended to write the Tetragrammaton, although he [inadvertently] inserted the daleth,10(10) Thus writing the noun correctly but without intention. he erases it and writes another Yehudah.11(11) Because the writing must be both intentional and correct.

RULE 5. If it was required to write the Tetragrammaton but [the scribe] intended to write Yehudah, although he inserted the daleth12(12) So that Yehudah was not only intended but also written correctly, in the wrong place. [Cf. the variant reading in Sof. V, 3.] he wipes away the final he and alters [the preceding] daleth into he.13(13) The letters being almost the same and the alteration so slight, the Tetragrammaton is deemed to have been written intentionally and correctly. R. Judah says: He should [also] go over the entire name with the reed-pen and so sanctify it. The Sages said to him: This is not the best procedure.

RULE 6. If in writing the Tetragrammaton he made an error [by omitting] one letter he should suspend it above [the line]. If one erred [by omitting] all the name14(14) The Tetragrammaton. he should suspend it between the lines. So R. Judah; R. Jose says: [The scribe] wipes away the letters preceding it, writes the Tetragrammaton [in their place] and suspends [above the line] the part which he had wiped away. R. Hananiah b. 'Aḳashia says: All the sheet must be stored away.

RULE 7. If one wrote Alef-lamed by mistake three15(15) So GRA in Sof. V, 5. V reads 'twice'. times in the clause God delivereth me to the ungodly,16(16) Job XVI, 11. The Biblical text has the word twice, the first being the name of God and the second the preposition, and inadvertently one wrote it three times, intending the first two to stand for 'God' (so sanctifying both) and the third for the preposition. one retains17(17) This is the reading in Sof. V, 5. V has 'wipes away'. the first and erases18(18) So GRA in Sof. V, 5. V has 'retains'. the latter.19(19) The second 'el which, having been intended in error to stand for the divine name, is treated in accordance with Rule 1 above. By quoting an illustration from Job, the inference to be drawn is that the regulation with respect to a Torah scroll holds good also of the Prophets and the Hagiographa.

RULE 8. When one is writing the Tetragrammaton, one may not respond even if the king greets him;20(20) All one's attention must be concentrated on the writing of the divine name. but if one was about to write two or three divine names successively21(21) e.g. The Lord, the Lord, God (Ex. XXXIV, 6) or Deut. VI, 4. one may pause between them and respond.

RULE 9. After dipping22(22) lit. 'he who dips'. the reed-pen [in ink], one may not start with a letter23(23) The text has me'otho, lit. 'from it'. A better reading, omitting the last waw would be me'oth, 'from a letter of'. of the divine name24(24) Because a pen full of ink may cause a blot. but with a letter of25(25) Reading again me'oth. the preceding word.

RULE 10. One who wipes away26(26) In Sof. V, 6, 'erases'. a single letter of a divine name transgresses a negative commandment. R. Ishmael27(27) 'R. Simeon' in Sof. loc. cit. says: On account of this it is stated, Ye shall destroy their name out of that place;28(28) Deut. XII, 3. and it is also stated, Ye shall not do so unto the Lord your God.29(29) ibid. 4; i.e. the name of God must never be erased. It is permissible, however, to wipe away ink that dropped on the writing,30(30) Even of a divine name. since one's intention is only to rectify it.

RULE 11. It is not permissible to make a scroll [of the Shema']31(31) So Sof. V, 9; lacking in V here. or of the Hallel for children.32(32) Extracts from the Scriptures may not be written on scrolls intended for children's instruction. R. Judah permits [the writing of a scroll] from In the beginning33(33) Gen. I, 1. to the story of the Flood,34(34) ibid. VI, 8. and from the beginning of Leviticus to And it came to pass on the eighth day;35(35) Lev. IX, 1. but [in the case of] all the other books [of Scripture the writing of extracts is] forbidden.36(36) Only in the case of the Pentateuch were the two extracts mentioned allowed to be written for the instruction of children. If, however, one intends to add to them,37(37) To complete all the book. it is permissible [to write extracts from the Scriptures in scrolls].

RULE 12. The following names are to be divided:38(38) Although each represents one name it is to be written as two words. Beth-'el,39(39) e.g. Gen. XII, 8. Beth-'awen,40(40) Hos. IV, 15; X, 5. Be'er-sheba',41(41) e.g. Gen. XXI, 31. Poṭifera',42(42) ibid. XXXV, 18. Ẓafenath-pa'neaḥ,43(43) ibid. XLI, 45. E.V. Poti-phera and Zaphenath-paneah. [and the words] ḥarah 'af,44(44) lit. 'the anger was kindled' (cf. Num. XI, 10). ḥarah 'appi.45(45) lit. 'My anger was kindled' (cf. Ex. XXII, 23). R. Jose says: These must not be divided. All agree that there must be no breaking up of 'Ammiel,46(46) A name meaning 'God is with me' (e.g. Num. XIII, 12). 'Amminadab,47(47) Meaning 'my kinsman is noble' (e.g. ibid. 23). Ẓuri'el,48(48) The name means 'my rock is God' (cf. ibid. III, 35). Ẓurishaddai.49(49) A name meaning 'my rock is Shaddai' (e.g. ibid. I, 6).

RULE 13. If a person writes a divine name on his body, he must neither bathe nor anoint himself.50(50) So that the name may not be washed off. R. Jose says: This is permitted provided only that he does not rub it off. [If he wrote it] on the horn of a cow or on the legs of a bed,51(51) For magical purposes. he scrapes it off52(52) [Perhaps the reading should be godedo, 'he chops it off' (the horn or the leg) for goreron, 'he scrapes them off' and stores it away.53(53) Out of respect for the divine name. The text has 'scrapes them … stores them'. [If he wrote it] on a stone, he detaches it and stores it away.

RULE 14. Should one cut off a strip of a scroll,54(54) lit. 'in scrolls'. it may [be used for ordinary purposes] if it is a new one,55(55) Being new, the scroll had not yet been consecrated. but if it is an old scroll56(56) Which has been consecrated for holy use. [the use of the strip] is forbidden. As regards worn-out scrolls, phylacteries and wraps of scrolls, these must be stored away.57(57) Having been once consecrated they may no longer be used for ordinary purposes. They should not be deposited [in an unclean place]58(58) The words in brackets are added in H. but in a deserted spot where they decay naturally.59(59) lit. 'of their own accord'.
